Gradient Descent

Pseudo Code

  • Start with an initial point for β\betaβ. Let this be β0\beta^0β0
  • Compute the gradient at β0\beta^0β0 to generate a better guess β1=β0−α∇βf(β0)\beta^1 = \beta^0 - \alpha\nabla_\beta f(\beta^0)β1=β0−α∇β​f(β0) where α\alphaα is the step size.
  • repeat this until βt\beta^tβt where α∇βf(βt)=0 \alpha\nabla_\beta f(\beta^t) = 0α∇β​f(βt)=0, or until ∣∣α∇βf(βt)∣∣≤ϵ|| \alpha\nabla_\beta f(\beta^t)|| \leq \epsilon∣∣α∇β​f(βt)∣∣≤ϵ where ϵ\epsilonϵ is some small scalar.

To get the gradient at each iteration we have to solve

∇βf(βt)=XT(Xβt−y)\nabla_\beta f(\beta^t) = X^T(X\beta^t - y)∇β​f(βt)=XT(Xβt−y)

  • Solving XβtX\beta^tXβt is O(nd)O(nd)O(nd)
  • Solving Xβt−yX\beta^t - yXβt−y is O(n)O(n)O(n)
  • Solving XT(Xβt−y)X^T(X\beta^t - y)XT(Xβt−y) is O(nd)O(nd)O(nd)

Therefore, the cost of gradient descent at each iteration is O(nd)O(nd)O(nd). So if we have ttt total iterations, the total cost of gradient descent is O(ndt)O(ndt)O(ndt).

The time complexity for solving OLS estimator is O(nd2+d3)O(nd^2 + d^3)O(nd2+d3). So if ddd is big, gradient descent may be a better alternative. Note that as nnn or ddd grow, then α\alphaα must be smaller for gradient descent to work.

Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD)

Since cost of gradient descent at each iteration is O(nd)O(nd)O(nd), cost of computation at each iteration becomes expensive as nnn grows.

Calculating the gradient using all nnn samples is the same as calculating the gradient using the average sample.

f(β)=∑i=1nfi(β)f(\beta) = \sum_{i=1}^n f_i(\beta)f(β)=∑i=1n​fi​(β)

f(β)=1n∑i=1nfi(β)f(\beta) = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n f_i(\beta)f(β)=n1​∑i=1n​fi​(β)

E(∇βf(βt))=∑i=1nP(i)∇βf(βt)=∑i=1n1n∇βf(βt)=1n∑i=1n∇βf(βt)=∇βf(βt)E\left(\nabla_\beta f(\beta^t)\right) = \sum_{i=1}^nP(i)\nabla_\beta f(\beta^t) = \sum_{i=1}^n\frac{1}{n}\nabla_\beta f(\beta^t) = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n\nabla_\beta f(\beta^t) = \nabla_\beta f(\beta^t)E(∇β​f(βt))=∑i=1n​P(i)∇β​f(βt)=∑i=1n​n1​∇β​f(βt)=n1​∑i=1n​∇β​f(βt)=∇β​f(βt)

Therefore, if we draw sub-samples randomly at each iteration we should get the same result as gradient descent; the gradient at each iteration will point to the right direction as the actual gradient on average.

Var(∇βf(βt))=E[(∇βf(βt)−E(∇βf(βt)))2]Var\left(\nabla_\beta f(\beta^t)\right) = E\left[\left(\nabla_\beta f(\beta^t) - E\left(\nabla_\beta f(\beta^t)\right)\right)^2\right]Var(∇β​f(βt))=E[(∇β​f(βt)−E(∇β​f(βt)))2]

Var(∇βf(βt))=1n∑i=1n(∇βf(βt)−∇βf(βt))2Var\left(\nabla_\beta f(\beta^t)\right) = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n\left(\nabla_\beta f(\beta^t) - \nabla_\beta f(\beta^t)\right)^2Var(∇β​f(βt))=n1​∑i=1n​(∇β​f(βt)−∇β​f(βt))2

  • If Variance is 000, every step goes in the right direction.
  • If Variance is small, most steps point in the right direction.
  • If variance is large, many steps will point in the wrong direction; This is when βt\beta^tβt is close to the global minimizer.

As step size α\alphaα increases variance increases as well. So Stochastic Gradient Descent can make an improvement by

  • Have α\alphaα be big when βt\beta^tβt is far from global minimizer
  • Have α\alphaα be small when βt\beta^tβt is close to global minimizer

Let αt\alpha^tαt be the step size at tttth iteration.

Stochastic gradient converges to a stationary point if

∑t=1∞(αt)2∑t=1∞αt=0\frac{\sum_{t=1}^\infty ({\alpha^t})^2}{\sum_{t=1}^\infty \alpha^t}=0∑t=1∞​αt∑t=1∞​(αt)2​=0

A solution for decreasing step sizes would be αt=O(1t)\alpha^t = O\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{t}}\right)αt=O(t​1​). If we don't really care about getting the exact solution we can just have αt=α\alpha^t = \alphaαt=α for all ttt.

In stochastic gradient descent we are not guaranteed to reach a gradient that will exactly equal 000. So in practice we can measure the validation set error after some iterations and stop the algorithm when the validation set error isn't improving.

There are multiple different ways where we can choose α\alphaα as well, such as Adam, batch-norm, min-batch etc.

Automatic Differentiation (AD)

Consider a function where the input is a function and the output is the derivative. This is Automatic Differentiation (AD), which is used when running gradient descents.

In deeper neural networks, the computation of the derivatives can get quite tedious, so instead of computing the gradient by hand use AD.

The idea behind AD is using chain rule from calculus.

Back Propagation

A dynamic programming approach to solving the chain rule is back propagation. There are 2 steps: forward path and backward path.

  • For each hidden layer, compute all forward paths W1x,W2h(W1x),…,vTh(… )W_1x, W_2h(W_1x), \dots, v^Th(\dots)W1​x,W2​h(W1​x),…,vTh(…).
  • Compute the backward paths using chain rule and store all the intermediate gradients starting from ∇fv\nabla f_{v}∇fv​, then all the way until ∇fW1\nabla f_{W_1}∇fW1​​.

Backpropagation requires significant storage capacity to hold all intermediate results during the computation process. Additionally, the computational cost of calculating the gradient is equivalent to the cost of computing the function itself.
